details.title: FARMOO - A VIRTUAL REALITY PAIN DISTRACTION

sections.title: Design Concept:
sections.text: The goal of Farmoo is to gamify the pain distraction experience for hospital patients in bed, particularly focusing on teenagers suffering from cancer. Since games are usually targeted as a means of entertainment, the team wants to provide a project aimed at the non-entertainment level by providing meaningful value within the game and virtual reality (VR) industry. Pain has been researched mostly with adults in comparison to teenagers and those who are younger. After harsh chemotherapy treatments, patients often experience pain and boredom when they are stuck in bed, where discomfort can be more extreme at a younger age.

Cancer patients require more care in comparison to patients with other serious illnesses due to the sickness impacts both physical and psychosocial aspects of the patient’s wellbeing. With a set audience in mind, the vision is to create a first-person farm life simulation game with a cute animal companion. Here, constant distraction can drive the pain away. The team hopes that the implicit metaphor of life can spark hope into cancer patient’s mind.
- Coming soon -

sections.title: My roles in Farmoo
sections.text: In Farmoo, I took on the role of the lead programmer, Unity3D engineer as well as game designer. As my partner Janice Ng was inexperience in Unity development, I let her handle the asset creations and technical writings. While I was in charge of building the world in Unity as well as programming game mechanics. As my first experience working with Oculus Rift and Leap Motion, I found that the difficulty bar raises up drastically when new tools are introduced. I was able to get both devices working with the Unity world, however it took far longer than I expected. As of this stage in development, the player will be able to navigate the farm game world we hand-crafted, and enjoy simple game-play in our rapid prototype. Moving forward, We would like to get feedback from the health workers, and ultimately from the cancer patients (target audience) to eliminate flaws and misconceptions in our game concept. I imagine optimization be vital in this application, as low frame-rates will induce unpleasant dizziness to our players in an virtual reality environment.

sections.title: Outcome
sections.text: Farmoo is still an on-going project. Check back again in later time for updates!

sections.title: Project Description
sections.text: Cleebo Casino is an online Free-to-Play social casino available to play on Facebook. Cleebo Casino provides players with the unique experience of playing their favourite casino games against a real live dealer located in Las Vegas. While a number of existing products allow players the same experience, Cleebo Casino is the first to provide this service as a Free-to-Play platform.

As Cleebo Casino is a Free-to-Play game a large portion of the project was focused on the development and implementation of social features. These features were intended to help distinguish Cleebo from its competitors, while also creating a sense of community between the players and even the live dealer.

details.title: ANATROC - A VIRTUAL REALITY PUZZLE ADVENTURE

sections.title: Design Concept:
sections.text: Anatroc is an immersive virtual reality puzzle adventure created for the Archiact Interactive Global Game Jam. Designed to test player's exploration skills, visual memory, and navigation skills as players explore the winding pathways of the maze. Decipher clues to uncover hidden pathways and perhaps even an exit. The original design of Anatroc was to create an immersive virtual reality experiences with two players cooperating with one another. To achieve this, the team researched the existing titles for Google Cardboard virtual reality headset. We found out that while there are a few PvP multiplayer games exist, but there were no cooperative multiplayer virtual reality titles available. We wanted to design Anatroc as the first cooperative multiplayer virtual reality experiences.

In its completion, Anatroc became a first person maze exploration game with both players taking unique roles. One player would take on the role of the maze avatar and would be forced to navigate the game's maze. The other player would take on the role of the first player's navigational AI. This player cannot move but has full access to a map of the maze. This map displays both players' locations and maze's doors and exit. Anatroc's gameplay will be formed through verbal communication between the two players in order to complete the maze. Both players are required to exchange clues in order to proceed in game levels. For example, the maze player will communicate a hint back to the AI player, for the AI player to unlock hidden doorways for maze player to explore. This game concept is based on numerous real-life escape room games in Vancouver, which I have personally researched on.

sections.title: My roles in Anatroc
sections.text: In Anatroc, I took on the role of the lead programmer. For my first step in developing the game, I started to experiment with the Google Cardboard SDK with Unity. I was responsible for majority of the game mechanics found in the maze. This includes but not limited to the movement mechanic, ray-casting mechanic, real-time minimap mechanic. I also used the scene loader to minimize the loads the device has to do. The experience was very valuable, as I learned in the progress, that it is much different to to design a game for desktop versus design a game for mobile. As mobile devices are not as powerful or as resourceful traditional computers, virtual reality games for mobile requires much delicate attentions to details. I spent several days finding ways to optimize Anatroc to run in reasonable framerates for mobile phones. I also worked with another programer in collaboration to create the virtual reality experiences.

sections.title: Outcome
sections.text: As a result Anatroc was selected as one of the 20 game jam finalists from over 100 individual submissions. We also finished in 4th place in the 'player's choice' voting portion of the contest. In reflection I maintain that it was the right decision to redesign Anatroc as a single player game given the time constraints. However, our team agree that Anatroc would have been a much more interesting and immersive experience with the multiplayer gameplay aspect intact. In summary I felt that competing in this game jam was a valuable experience in learning to design in virtual reality, and also in completing a project under a strict deadline. Perhaps it would be worth while to reapproach it.

sections.title: Design Concept:
sections.text: The AFK (Away From Keyboard) game development symposium is an event designed to provide a platform for passionate SIAT undergraduates with game design focus to showcase their work to an industry audience. Throughout the school term, students were encouraged to submit their game projects to one of the four event categories: Narrative, Immersion, Artificial Intelligence, Level Design

From each category, one project was selected as representative in front of a panel of four Vancouver games industry judges, as well as the attendees mixed of students, industry professionals and school faculty members. The attendees were also invited to the post-event mixer for a chance to network with the local game industry professionals and jumpstart their careers. In addition to student projects, AFK symposium also featured two talks delivered by SIAT PhD faculty. The postgraduate talks focused on academic researches involving expanding video games beyond traditional entertainments.

sections.title: My roles in AFK
sections.text: In both planning and running the event, I took on the role of event planner and technology officer. I was approached by Sean Warwick, who initialized the idea to create AFK based on TouchPoint, a similar design conference held at SFU focusing on user experience design. I joined the AFK organization committee as I was fond of the idea to give back to the university and provide a platform to assist newcomers in the program. I was involved in choosing of representatives from each category and provided comments and assisted presenters on how to present during the event to ensure the highest quality possible. On the day of the event, I was in charged of technology equipments required for the conference - that includes and not limited to, making sure the selected projects will operate fine on the projectors, the amount of microphones and the sound and lighting of the venue.

sections.title: Outcome
sections.text: Overall, I believe the AFK organization committee did great. Considering that it was our first iteration of the event, it was highly successful. We had a total of 110 tickets sold, with roughly 70 attendees attending the day of the event. The panelists included representatives from successful studios including: East Side Games, Roadhouse Interactive, Relic Entertainment, IUGO Mobile Entertainment. We were also happy to feature an opening talk by Dave Fracchia from the Centre of Digital Media. Perks for attendees included door prizes totaling $175 in value as well as catered breakfast, lunch and dinner.

Due to the highly positive reception, the SIAT event planning staffs plan to continue partnership with us to develop AFK into an annual event with full support. To ensure that the event remains a student led initiative, we have invited some of the presenters to take over as next year's organization committee. I will instead take on a supporting mentor role to provide guidance when needed.

sections.title: Design Concept:
sections.text: This website was a side-project done with a friend. We wanted to create a new way to receive information. In nowadays, social news feed flood our devices every minute and it is hard to filter out the ones we need. So why not have an universal view to look at all your feeds in a grid layout.

The search function will help you filter out the feed by hash tags. These hash tags are user-created to the photos. InStream aims to be as user intuitive as possible, user interactions are as simple as type and photos will appear.

sections.title: Tools Used:
sections.text: HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript, JQuery, Material Design, Instagram API, RESTful web service

sections.title: Design Concept:
sections.text: This was a group project for a course that taught user-centred design and software design and development methods. In our team of four, we conceptualized and created a prototype for Notif, a concept mapping tool targeted towards the academic teaching and learning domain. We decided to do our prototype in Flash.

What notably sets this apart from existing brainstorming / mind-mapping tools is that, for student collaborators, it supports real-time collaboration, and suggests connections between concepts based on the similarities between them. For mentors, such as course instructors, they have the ability to allow students to upload their concept maps to a central folder; our application may aggregate and view a list of the most used connections between concepts, and additionally mass publish feedback to students with those connection patterns.
The design and functionality of our tool was heavily use-case and scenario drive. My main role within the project was implementing the prototype and to conduct the user-studies.
